body.name: More Than Grit: A coming of age novel based on a true story from the Depression era
body.description: When do secrets become lies? When is grit not enough? A story of broken lives and deep friendships, inspired by true events in 1939, when the shadows of World War II lengthened.Scarred by burns from a kerosene lantern, twelve-year old Sissy knows electricity is more than her farm family’s dream. It’s vital. She also knows they can’t afford the required deposit to be connected to electric lines, so she wrangles a secret deal in order to help her parents. As she faces danger and sacrifices to support her family, Sissy’s best efforts fail. She’s blind to what she needs most, and when she finally tells her secrets, she fears it’s too late.Set in Kansas farmland, More than Grit is an unforgettable story of determination to succeed against all odds and will appeal to middle-grade and teen readers, their parents, and anyone who roots for the underdog.Award winning author Gretchen A. Carlson fills her characters with grit and grace as she shares the story her grandmother kept secret.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 7, 2024
reviews.reviewText: I absolutely loved this book! I had been reading non fiction war stories and needed uplifting and lighter material. It was a beautiful story from start to finish and I could hardly put it down!! I would highly recommend this book to people of all ages!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 25, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars A wonderful story with meaning.
reviews.reviewText: Since I read a lot of heavier none fiction, spiritual, political, historical books, i always include something lighter. While some books might be lighter but totally meaningless. This one fits the bill of having a plot, underlying meaning without preaching and easy to read.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 16, 2022
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Meaningful tale about trust and hard work
reviews.reviewText: In 1939 a young girl named Sissy shimmies up a tree to ‘borrow’ apples from the crazy old war vet, unaware her life will change forever.Sissy desires to help her family in their financial trouble and is tired of being treated like a child. After the old man lowers his gun and agrees not to shoot her for stealing, Sissy strikes deal with him. In exchange for eggs, she will work on his farm and clean out his chicken shed.If she sells enough eggs, she can help her family make the five-dollar deposit for electricity and do away with their dangerous kerosene lamps. Her strategy is sound, but of course, nothing goes as planned. A harsh bully, curious parents, unpredictable weather, and a close friend’s troubles make her scheme nearly impossible.Sissy blocks everyone out so her plan will work but, in the process, she cuts out her parents who could help. As her world comes crashing down, she realizes she should have asked for help and wonders how she can fix what is broken.This is an amazing story about hard work, faith, and trust. It deals with tough topics like racism, abuse, poverty, and dishonesty all while staying safe for middle-grade readers.I loved Sissy’s bulldog determination to help her family and protect her friend against prejudiced actions. Sissy's stubborn spirit reminded me of my own and I could see my younger self striving to do things the hard way.If you have young readers at home or in your family, I highly recommend this book. It would be great for any homeschool curriculum because as historical fiction it shows the mindset and differentiating opinions of the war and the culture that thrived in the 1930s. I loved reading Little House On The Prairie growing up and this reminded me of that but with its own flavor of storytelling.I give it 5 stars for cleanliness.5 Stars for keeping interest and tensionAnd 5 stars for staying true to morals and the Christian worldview.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 30, 2022
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars A wonderful story
reviews.reviewText: A wonderful story made even better by the fact that it's based on a true event. I would recommend this book to young people and to those who have lived through changing technologies...which includes everyone born before 2010!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 22, 2022
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Middle Grade Historical Fiction at its Finest!
reviews.reviewText: More than Grit whisks you away to a Kansas farm in the fall of 1939. Experience history through the eyes of twelve-year-old Sissy, as she navigates hardships at home, school, community, and even abroad, as the world processes the horrors happening in Europe.Heart-warming themes of friendship, bravery, and grace are interwoven into the story. While Sissy's life is full of challenges, you will find glimmers of joy throughout. Be sure to keep the tissue box close by, as I know I teared up more than once!I adore that this book is based on a true story, and Carlson artfully brings it to life with her skillful writing. A glossary of historical references is provided at the end of the book, which is very helpful for young readers to grasp this time in history. Discussion questions and activities for each chapter of More than Grit are found on Gretchen Carlson's website, making this a perfect book for any educator.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 6, 2022
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Determination against all odds
reviews.reviewText: For fans of Because of Winn Dixie and Sour Lemon and Sweet Tea comes a story of fighting for what you love against all odds. In 1939, few farms in rural Kansas had electricity. After 12-year-old Sissy‘s face burns and scars from a kerosene lamp, Sissy will do anything to help her family afford electricity. After school, Sissy secretly works for the town’s grumpy old farmer who wants nothing more than to get rid of her, but Sissy perseveres, earning enough money to put down a deposit with the electrical company. When her cash is stolen, Sissy suspects the school bully and is heart-broken when she learns a friend betrayed her. Out of options, the town comes together determined to see Sissy succeed.Based on a true story, Carlton shares the story her grandmother kept secrets for years in her debut novel, More Than Grit. Perfect for tweens, class read-along, elementary school students, and middle school students.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 16, 2022
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Surviving the hard times is not for the faint of heart
reviews.reviewText: Way back in elementary school, my 6th grade teacher stood at the front of the class each day and read a chapter to the class from various books during free time. In reading More Than Grit, I couldn't help comparing it to Little Britches, the early life of Ralph Moody. Both books made the story of hardship, friendship and forgiveness come alive and magnified the sacrifices needed to overcome not just for the character, but for the good of the family and the community.Sissy's scars didn't make her hide in shame. They made her a protector who measured grace and forgiveness in exemplary fashion. I was rooting for her from page 1.It's too bad teachers no longer read to their classes. If they did, More Than Grit should top the list of reads.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 30, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Intriguing story with historical significance
reviews.reviewText: A lovely cast of characters bring to life the realities of a time unknown to many readers. Middle grade children will be intrigued by the meshing of the simpler yet oh-so-challenging times depicted in More Than Grit. Folks of all ages will learn from the rich historic background woven into the story. And how special that it springs from actual events.
